english_translation: Genealogy of Suwayd ibn Ghafalah ibn Awsajah ibn Amir ibn Wadaa ibn Muawiyah ibn al-Harith ibn Malik ibn Awf ibn Sa'd ibn Awf ibn Harim ibn Ja'fi ibn Sa'd al-Ashirah.

chainIssues: This is a genealogical entry with no isnad chain

potential_issues.impact: This entry contains only genealogical information without any chain of transmission. It cannot be classified as a hadith in the traditional sense.
This is a genealogical listing, not a narrated tradition from the Prophet ﷺ or the Companions

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Genealogy of Suwayd ibn Ghafalah

english_translation: Suwayd ibn Ghafalah was from Mudhaj. He saw the Prophet ﷺ but found him already deceased. He accompanied Abu Bakr, Uthman, and Ali. He witnessed the Battle of Siffin with Ali. He heard from Abdullah ibn Mas'ud but did not hear anything from Uthman. His kunya was Abu Umayyah.

chainIssues: This is biographical information without a proper isnad chain

potential_issues.impact: This is biographical information about Suwayd ibn Ghafalah without any transmission chain
The source of this biographical information is not specified, making verification impossible

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Biography of Suwayd ibn Ghafalah
Companionship of the Companions with various early leaders

english_translation: Narrated by Suwayd ibn Ghafalah: The tax collector of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ came to us. I took his hand and read the sealed orders that he carried. In them it stated: 'Do not separate those united together, nor unite those separated.' Then a man brought him a great strong camel, but he refused to take it. Then another brought him a weaker camel, but he also refused it. Then he said: 'What sky would shelter me and what earth would carry me if I came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and had taken the best camels of a Muslim man?'

Both Uthman al-Thaqafi and Abu Layla al-Kindi use عَنْ (from) which could indicate indirectness, though direct liqa' is likely given the proximity of generations

english_translation: Narrated by Suwayd ibn Ghafalah: I was calling the Adhan at noon. Al-Hajjaj heard it while at the monastery and said: 'Bring me this one who gives the Adhan.' When Suwayd came, al-Hajjaj asked: 'What made you call the Adhan at noon?' Suwayd replied: 'I did it with Abu Bakr and Umar.' Then al-Hajjaj said: 'Do not call the Adhan for your people, nor lead them in prayer.' Al-Hajjaj commanded them to remove him from calling the Adhan and leading prayer. Also it is mentioned that Suwayd ibn Ghafalah was hiding during the time of al-Hajjaj, and people used to pray the Zuhr on Friday in congregation. Additionally, Suwayd ibn Ghafalah used to pass by us in the mosque to his wife from Bani Asad, and he was one hundred twenty-seven years old, sometimes he would bow and sometimes he would not. Also, Suwayd ibn Ghafalah shrouded al-Ubayriq ibn Malik in two garments.

english_translation: Suwayd ibn Ghafalah made a will saying: When I die, do not announce my death to anyone, do not place plaster or bricks around my grave, do not place wood there, and do not let a woman accompany me. Shroud me only in my own garments. It is mentioned that Suwayd ibn Ghafalah died in Kufa in the year 81 or 82 AH during the caliphate of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, and al-Fadl ibn Dukain said he died at the age of 128 years.

english_translation: Genealogy of al-Aswad ibn Yazid ibn Qays ibn Abdullah ibn Malik ibn Alqamah ibn Salamah ibn Kahl ibn Bakr ibn Awf ibn al-Nakha'

chainIssues: Genealogical entry without isnad

potential_issues.impact: This is purely genealogical information without transmission chain

IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Genealogy of al-Aswad ibn Yazid

english_translation: Al-Aswad ibn Yazid was from Mudhaj with the kunya Abu Amr. He was the uncle of Alqamah ibn Qays, and al-Aswad was older than Alqamah. He brought the dower of Alqamah's mother. Al-Aswad narrated from Abu Bakr al-Siddiq that he performed the hajj with him. He also narrated from Umar, Ali, Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, Mu'adh ibn Jabal (whom he heard from in Yemen before his migration when the Prophet ﷺ sent Mu'adh to Yemen), Salman, Abu Musa, and Aisha, but he did not narrate anything from Uthman. It is mentioned that al-Aswad used to fast perpetually. Also, al-Aswad used to fast even on intensely hot days when even strong red camels would stagger from the heat. Additionally, al-Aswad would fast during journeys until his tongue would turn black from the heat, while his companions would drink several times before finishing their journey on non-Ramadan days.

chainIssues: Initial biographical information without chain

english_translation: Narrated by Hanash: I saw al-Aswad and one of his eyes had gone due to fasting. Also narrated: I traveled with al-Aswad to Makkah. When the time of prayer came, he would descend in any condition he was in. If he was on rough ground, he would descend and pray. If his camel was ascending or descending, he would stop and not wait. Also: al-Aswad would stop his camel when prayer time came, even if on a stone. Moreover: al-Aswad circumambulated the Kaaba eighty times between Hajj and Umrah. Al-Aswad would enter the state of ihram from his house, while Alqamah would enjoy his garments. Both Fadl ibn Dukain and Muhammad ibn Abdullah al-Asadi narrated: Sufyan narrated from Mansur from Ibrahim that al-Aswad would enter ihram from his house while Alqamah would benefit from his clothes. Also: I saw al-Aswad and Amr ibn Maymun entering ihram from Kufa. Furthermore, al-Aswad would leave Kufa in the state of ihram with matted hair. Also: I saw al-Aswad ibn Yazid enter ihram from Bajumayra.

chainIssues: Short chain with direct observation
